stories.text:
I am in second year studying Economics and am looking into options for when I graduate. The typical roles for Economics tend to be in banking, finance and consulting. However, I think that I could develop a better career and be far happier in the tech industry. I am not that interested in going down a super technical route involving software development so this post is me trying to work out what other options are available.

So far I have really enjoyed microeconomics, environmental economics, finance (I like the concepts, not the idea of the finance industry), statistics, data science and policy issues. I know this is quite broad, but this is why I am trying to explore different options.

I would be very interested in hearing peoples experiences, and seeing what roles are out there for a non-technical role at large, medium and start-up companies.

What are my options?
stories.title: Ask HN: I am studying economics and want to work in Tech. How?

stories.text:
One would think that over the last decades, with a countless number of smart people, there would be a Linux distro on the level of macOS. I am talking about a distro, that you don't have to configure anything for. A distro that handles things like external devices screen recording without weird glitches. A distro that is _worry free_ and that _just works_.
Why do you think that is the case? Or am I simply ignorant of the current state of Linux distros?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why is there no Linux distro that “just works” like macOS?
Counting Sheets Is More Complex Than It Seems: On Origami Classification Part II
